questions.text: You are presenting a case of acute rheumatic fever, and post the presentation, the sr asks you about the late manifestations of arf. Which of the following will be considered a late manifestation?

options.label: A
options.text: Carditis

options.label: B
options.text: Arthritis

options.label: C
options.text: Erythema marginatum

options.label: D
options.text: Chorea

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chorea Early manifestations Late manifestations A. Carditis Chorea B. Arthritis Subcutaneous nodules C.Erythema marginatum

questions.text: Which of the following is false concerning rheumatic fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Arthritis in rheumatic fever usually affects the small joints and leaves residual damage

options.label: B
options.text: Subcutaneous nodules are associated with carditis

options.label: C
options.text: Chorea occurs more frequently in females than males

options.label: D
options.text: Erythema marginatum lessons are usually induced by heat

questions.correct_answer: A. Arthritis in rheumatic fever usually affects the small joints and leaves residual damage
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arthritis in rheumatic fever usually affects the small joints and leaves residual damage Arthritis: No residual damage Involves large joints Subcutaneous nodules: late manifestation, non-tender Usually associated with carditis Chorea Late manifestations Semi-purposeful jerky movements Females >> males Erythema marginatum Annular/ serpiginous lesions Usually present on tunk Induced by heat

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes to the clinic with a fever, multiple joint pain, and a non-itching red rash with a pale center spread over the trunk. Which of the following is true about the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: It is caused by antibodies produced against Group B beta-hemolytic streptococci

options.label: B
options.text: Only the heart valves are permanently damaged during an episode of this disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Sydenham’s chorea occurs immediately after the onset of acute rheumatic fever.

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated levels of antistreptolysin O (ASO) are diagnostic of this disease.

questions.correct_answer: B. Only the heart valves are permanently damaged during an episode of this disease.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Only the heart valves are permanently damaged during an episode of this disease. The boy's history has three major criteria according to revised Jones criteria (only two major or one major and two minor criteria are required to make a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever).

Highyeild:

During an episode of rheumatic fever, only heart valves are permanently damaged, whereas pericarditis, chorea, and arthritis resolve completely. The most common valve involved is the Mitral valve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Rheumatic fever is caused due to antibodies produced against cell wall proteins of Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. Option C. Sydenham’s chorea, which is one of the major criteria, occurs about three months after the onset of the rheumatic fever. Option D. Elevated levels of antistreptolysin O (ASO) indicate previous streptococcal infection and not rheumatic fever.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to the clinic with a fever, multiple joint pains, and chorea. History of sore throat present ten days ago. Further history taking reveals she comes from an area where the incidence of rheumatic fever is 1/100,000 among the school-going age group. Which of the following is not a minor criterion according to revised Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Polyarthralgia

options.label: B
options.text: ESR ≥ 30 mm/hr

options.label: C
options.text: Fever ≥ 38.5˚C

options.label: D
options.text: Prolonged PR interval

questions.explanation:
Solution:

ESR ≥ 30 mm/hr Minor criteria include ESR ≥ 60 mm/hr not ≥ 30 mm/hr.

Highyeild:

The American Heart Association (AHA) revised the Jones criteria in 2015 to diagnose acute rheumatic fever (ARF). The updated criteria include: Major criteria: Clinical or subclinical carditis Arthritis (monoarthritis or polyarthritis) Polyarthralgia Chorea Erythema marginatum Subcutaneous nodules Minor criteria: Prolonged PR interval Arthralgia Fever Markers of inflammation Low-risk populations are defined as where the incidence of rheumatic fever < 2/100,000 in school-going children and rheumatic heart disease prevalence < 1/1000.

Random:

Option A, B, C & D. Hence, this question shows that the girl belongs to a low-risk population. In low-risk populations, minor criteria include polyarthralgia, fever ≥ 38.5˚C, ESR ≥ 60 mm/hr ; CRP ≥3.0 mg/dl, prolonged PR interval (suggestive of AV Block or slow conduction).

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the clinic with joint pain, fever, and rashes. Laboratory investigation shows elevated levels of ASO titers and CRP. History reveals she comes from an area where the incidence of rheumatic fever is 3/100,000 in school-going children and the prevalence of rheumatic heart disease is 2/1000. Which of the following is not a major criterion in the Revised Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever?

options.label: A
options.text: Carditis

options.label: B
options.text: Monoarthritis

options.label: C
options.text: Polyarthralgia

options.label: D
options.text: Monoarthralgia

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Monoarthralgia Revised Jones criteria for acute rheumatic fever lists out major and minor criteria for high-risk and low-risk populations Monoarthralgia is a minor criteria in high-risk populations. In low-risk populations, minor criteria include polyarthralgia, fever ≥ 38.5˚C, ESR ≥ 60 mm/hr; CRP ≥3.0 mg/dl, prolonged PR interval (suggestive of AV Block or slow conduction).

Highyeild:

High-risk populations are defined as where the incidence of rheumatic fever > 2/100,000 in school-going children and rheumatic heart disease prevalence >1/1000.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A, B, C. This question shows that the girl belongs to a high-risk population. Major criteria for high-risk population includes clinical or subclinical carditis, polyarthritis or monoarthritis, polyarthralgia, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic complaining of fever, chest pain, and joint pain. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation, and a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever was made. Which of the following is not an auscultatory finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Soft first heart sound

options.label: B
options.text: Decrescendo diastolic murmur at pulmonic area

options.label: C
options.text: Delayed diastolic mitral murmur

options.label: D
options.text: Pan systolic murmur at apex radiating to the left axilla.

questions.correct_answer: B. Decrescendo diastolic murmur at pulmonic area
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Decrescendo diastolic murmur at pulmonic area Because of less common involvement of this valve. Mitral, aortic and tricuspid valves are involved in rheumatic fever carditis. Decrescendo diastolic murmur at the pulmonic area is due to pulmonary valve regurgitation, which is not seen in rheumatic fever carditis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Soft first heart sound is heard due to involvement of the mitral valve Option C. Carey Coomb’s murmur is heard in rheumatic fever carditis. This is a soft, delayed diastolic mitral murmur due to blood flowing across the inflamed and thickened mitral valve. Option D. pansystolic murmur at the apex radiating to the left axilla is due to mitral regurgitation , which is seen in 95% of cases of rheumatic fever carditis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with fever, chest pain, and multiple joint pain ten days after an episode of sore throat. He has had a similar episode of acute rheumatic fever in the past. Which of the following is true about the prevention of this disease?

options.label: A
options.text: At this stage, prevention will be primary prevention.

options.label: B
options.text: Secondary prevention includes 12 million units of benzathine penicillin every three weeks.

options.label: C
options.text: Patients without proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for five years after the last episode or until they are 18.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for five years after the last episode or until they are 25.

questions.correct_answer: C. Patients without proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for five years after the last episode or until they are 18.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patients without proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for five years after the last episode or until they are 18. Secondary prophylaxis includes that patients without proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for five years after the last episode or until they are 18 years old, whichever is longer.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. As the patient already has an active episode of rheumatic fever , starting prophylactic measures now would be called secondary prevention. Primary prevention requires the identification of streptococcal sore throat and its prompt treatment with penicillin. Option B. Secondary prevention of acute rheumatic fever involves giving an intramuscular injection of benzathine penicillin 1.2 million units every three weeks or 0.6 million units every alternate week. Option D. Patients with proven carditis should receive prophylaxis for ten years after the last episode or until they are 25. This will ensure the treatment of any residual heart lesion and the prevention of endocarditis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with severe cough and dyspnea developing over the past week. On examination, the patient has tachycardia. Soon after admission, his saturation dropped, and he developed respiratory arrest. Autopsy reveals the following a lesion in heart valves: What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Infective endocarditis

options.label: B
options.text: Rheumatic heart disease

options.label: C
options.text: Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Pulmonary embolism

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rheumatic heart disease The image shows Aschoff nodules present in heart valves which indicates active inflammation. The history suggests of rheumatic heart disease with severe mitral regurgitation resulting in left ventricular failure and pulmonary congestion. Tachycardia occurs to compensate for heart failure. So, that adequate cardiac output is maintained.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Infective endocarditis can cause congestive heart failure but biopsy of the valves would show inflammatory cells and not Aschoff bodies. Option C. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy patients present with exertional dyspnea, anginal pain, palpitation, syncope and sudden death. Heart valves are not involved and there is no significant inflammation seen in biopsy. Option D. Pulmonary embolism: It is very acute in onset and symptoms include severe chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy with a history of 3 episodes of rheumatic fever presents for a routine check-up. Three-dimensional echocardiography of the mitral valve shows a similar picture: Which of the following is true about the treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Beta blockers are contraindicated

options.label: B
options.text: Trans-septal mitral commissurotomy is indicated

options.label: C
options.text: Diuretics are contraindicated

options.label: D
options.text: Risk of restenosis after valvotomy is negligible

questions.correct_answer: B. Trans-septal mitral commissurotomy is indicated
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Trans-septal mitral commissurotomy is indicated The image shows rheumatic mitral stenosis with a characteristic “fish mouth” This is helpful in treating the stenotic mitral valve.

Highyeild:

Balloon mitral valvotomy or percutaneous trans-septal mitral commissurotomy has replaced closed or open commissurotomy for MS

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Beta blockers or digoxin should be given to these patients by reducing resting and exercise heart rates and thus improving diastolic filling. Option C. Diuretics help by reducing pulmonary venous congestion. Option D. Long-term follow-up after valvotomy is mandatory because of the significant risk of restenosis with time.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with a known case of rheumatic heart disease comes for a regular follow-up. Which of the following is false about valves involved in rheumatic heart disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Mitral regurgitation is most commonly seen

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic regurgitation is often seen along with Mitral regurgitation

options.label: C
options.text: Pure aortic regurgitation is more commonly seen than mitral stenosis

options.label: D
options.text: Tricuspid regurgitation is seen in 20-50% patients of RHD.

questions.correct_answer: C. Pure aortic regurgitation is more commonly seen than mitral stenosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pure aortic regurgitation is more commonly seen than mitral stenosis In RHD, mitral stenosis is the second most common after mitral regurgitation. Mitral Stenosis usually occurs in chronic RHD. Pure aortic regurgitation is rare and occurs in around 5% of cases.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Mitral regurgitation is seen in 80-85% of cases Option B. Aortic regurgitation along with mitral regurgitation is seen in 25% of cases Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation is seen in 20-50% of patients of RHD in children.

questions.text: The mother of a 2-month-old infant brings her child to the clinic with complaints of increased breaks between feeds, irritability and crying excessively, and facial puffiness. On auscultation, an S3 gallop is heard and confirmed that the baby was in congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following is not a cause of diastolic heart failure?

options.label: A
options.text: Mitral stenosis

options.label: B
options.text: Aortic stenosis

options.label: C
options.text: Restrictive cardiomyopathy

options.label: D
options.text: Ventricular hypertrophy

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aortic stenosis Cardiac failures can be divided into systolic and diastolic failures. Aortic stenosis causes decreased cardiac output and thus causes systolic failure

Highyeild:

Systolic failure refers to the heart's inability to meet the body's metabolic needs. Diastolic failure refers to the inability of the ventricles to get filled during diastole. This can be associated with S4 (Fourth heart sound)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Mitral stenosis prevents blood from the left atrium from flowing into the left ventricle and thus causes inadequate filling of the ventricular cavity. Option C. Restrictive cardiomyopathy prevents ventricles from expanding during diastole and thus reduces its filling. Option D. In ventricular hypertrophy, the volume of the ventricular cavities is reduced and thus causing reduced filling.

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant presents with poor weight gain, decreased feeding, excessive crying, and lower limb swelling. Laboratory investigation shows hemoglobin of 5g/dl. Which of the following will not help in the treatment of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Reducing cardiac work

options.label: B
options.text: Correcting the underlying cause

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing venous return

options.label: D
options.text: Intravenous inotropic agents

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increasing venous return The question point towards severe anemia in failure. This can be treated by reducing cardiac output, correcting the underlying causes, and IV inotropic agents but not increasing venous return. Reducing venous return (preload) is done by administering diuretics. This reduces heart size. The larger the heart, the more the wall tension and the poorer is the performance. With the reduction in heart size and volume, the myocardial function and the cardiac outcome improve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Reducing cardiac work: By correcting anemia, restricting activities, and mechanical ventilation. Option B. Underlying causes such as CHD , coarctation of the aorta, etc, should be diagnosed early and treated curatively or palliatively. Option D. IV inotropes such as dopamine, amrinone, and levosimendan are used in different settings to help in increasing myocardial contractility.

questions.text: A 1-year-old infant is brought to the clinic with lower limb swelling, wheezing, increased breaks between feeds, and forehead sweating. Pediatrician plans to augment myocardial contractility by administering digoxin. Which of the following is false regarding digoxin treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: It has delayed the onset of action.

options.label: B
options.text: Children are digitalized within a 24-hour period, followed by a maintenance dose.

options.label: C
options.text: Digoxin toxicity is monitored by looking at PR interval

options.label: D
options.text: Digitalizing dose is between 0.04 to 0.08 mg/kg.

questions.correct_answer: A. It has delayed the onset of action.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It has delayed the onset of action. Digoxin has a rapid onset of action and is eliminated rapidly. Digoxin is eliminated by kidneys, so it can accumulate in renal failure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B. Children are digitalized within a 24-hour Half the calculated digitalizing dose is given initially, followed by ¼ in 6-8 hours and the final ¼ after another 6-8 hours. The maintenance dose is ¼ of the digitalizing dose. Option C. Before the third daily dose, an ECG is obtained, and if the PR interval exceeds the initial interval by 50% , digitalis toxicity is present. (Upper limit of normal PR interval in infants is 0.14 seconds) Option D. Digitalizing dose in neonates is 0.04 mg/kg, one month to 1 year: 0.08 mg/kg, 1 to 3 years: 0.06 mg/kg, > three years: 0.04 mg/kg .

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with lower limb swelling, palpitations, and increased respiratory rate was brought to the clinic three days back, following which she was started on oral digoxin. Her ECG shows a PR interval of 0.12 seconds. What would you do next?

options.label: A
options.text: Omit the next two doses.

options.label: B
options.text: Stop digoxin and switch to ACE inhibitors

options.label: C
options.text: No change in treatment is needed.

options.label: D
options.text: Decrease the maintenance dose of digoxin

questions.correct_answer: C. No change in treatment is needed.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No change in treatment is needed. Before the third daily dose, an ECG is obtained, and if the PR interval exceeds the initial interval by 50%, digitalis toxicity is present. (Upper limit of normal PR interval in infants is 0.14 seconds)

Highyeild:

PR interval is in normal limit and hence no change in treatment is needed because digitalis toxicity is less likely here.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. If the PR interval exceeds 0.14 seconds, the next one or two doses should be omitted. Option B & D. There is no indication to stop or decrease digoxin. Digoxin can be combined with ACE inhibitors for a synergistic effect.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant with VSD is brought to the clinic with poor weight gain, increased breaks between feeds, fast breathing, and cough. Pediatrician decides to start him with IV dobutamine. Which of the following is true about using inotropes in congestive cardiac failure?

options.label: A
options.text: Dopamine should be used at a dose of 20 µg/kg/min

options.label: B
options.text: In patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, dobutamine is used

options.label: C
options.text: Levosimendan acts by opening potassium channels

options.label: D
options.text: Milrinone is a calcium sensitizer used as a potent indicator

questions.correct_answer: B. In patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, dobutamine is used
questions.explanation:
Solution:

In patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, dobutamine is used In patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, dobutamine is used as 24 hours infusion once a week because Dobutamine helps to increase contractility of the heart.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A. Dopamine is given at a dose of less than five µg/kg/min, and this dose causes peripheral vasodilation and increases myocardial contractility. Option C. Levosimendan is a calcium sensitizer used in acute care settings as a potent indicator causing systemic and coronary vasodilation. Option D. Milrinone and amrinone are phosphodiesterase inhibitors.
